doc:div.p: Our goal is to streamline the server installation process such that on Linux you can have RabbitMQ up and running within two minutes of completing your download. If this doesn't happen to you, please let us know at legitimategrievance@rabbitmq.com!
The RabbitMQ server is an implementation of an AMQP broker. Please see the specification page for more information on AMQP interoperation and standards-conformance.

RabbitMQ is written on top of the widely-used Open Telecom Platform, and is platform neutral; the binary distributions listed below differ only in how they are packaged to conform to various operating systems' packaging conventions.
Please refer to the platforms page to see if RabbitMQ is supported on your operating system.

RabbitMQ server uses Erlang/OTP, so a recent version of Erlang must be installed to run or compile the server. Your operating system may provide an Erlang package, or you may need to get it from http://www.erlang.org/download.html.
Please see the installation instructions. Additional documentation can be found linked from our documentation page.
The server is open-source, and is licensed under the Mozilla Public License v1.1.
The current release of the RabbitMQ Server is &version-server;.
The server is available in several compiled forms, or as source. Notes on particular operating systems and variants can be found below the download table.

The openSUSE RPM files are intended for Novell's openSUSE Linux and derived distributions (SLES and SLERT). We haven't tested these under recent releases, but expect that they work.
If you have success using our RPMs with any other RPM-based distribution, please let us know.

We strongly recommend using your distribution's packaged version of Erlang to run the server. This is part of Fedora, and in EPEL for RHEL. To enable EPEL on your Red Hat machine, see the EPEL FAQ. Then just yum install erlang.

Note to users of RHEL 5 and derived distributions (e.g. CentOS 5): Due to the EPEL package update policy, EPEL 5 contains Erlang version R12B-5, which is relatively old. rabbitmq-server supports R12B-5, but performance may be lower than for more recent Erlang versions, and certain non-core features are not supported (SSL support, HTTP-based plugins). Therefore, we recommend that you install the most recent stable version of Erlang. The easiest way to do this is to use a package repository provided for this purpose by the owner of the EPEL Erlang package. Enable it by invoking (as root):
and then install or update erlang with yum install erlang.
On OS X the server can be installed via MacPorts.
